Article Ru-Co single-atom alloy catalysts for efficient amination of alcohols: A synergistic effect Zhitong Zhou a b Weixiang Guan a Xiaoli Pan a Shengxin Zhang a b Yang Su a Aiqin Wang a * Tao Zhang a b * a State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian Liaoning 116023 China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China * Corresponding author Synthesis of primary amines from alcohols is an economical and green route to access high-value N-compounds. However, challenges remain to develop both cost-effective and efficient catalysts. In this study, we developed a Ru-Co/ZrO2 single-atom alloy catalyst which afforded diverse primary amines from alcohols in the presence of ammonia and hydrogen with exceptional conversion (up to 90%) and selectivity (80%) under mild conditions (0.7 MPa NH3, 0.3 MPa H2, 160 °C) and exhibited satisfactory stability upon regeneration. The turnover rate was approximately 8.4 times higher than that observed over the Co/ZrO2 catalyst. Characterizations indicated that the alloyed Ru facilitated the reduction of Co, strengthened the interaction with H2 and mitigated the over-strong adsorption of aldehyde intermediates. These combined effects contributed significantly to the enhanced catalytic performances. This work presents a promising strategy for the development of advanced catalysts in the amination of alcohols. Graphical Abstract The Ru-Co/ZrO2 single-atom alloy catalyst exhibited a broad scope and satisfactory yields to primary amines. The synergistic effect between Ru and Co resulted in a turnover rate approximately 8.4 times higher than that of Co/ZrO2. Keywords Alcohols amination Ammonia Single-atom alloy catalyst Ru-Co Primary amine 1 Introduction Primary amines are extensively used in the manufacture of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and material science [1]. Among various reported methods to access primary amines, the direct amination of alcohols with ammonia is most promising and environmentally benign since alcohols can be derived from renewable biomass and the sole byproduct is water [2–4]. It is generally accepted that the alcohol amination reaction is composed of three steps [5,6]: (1) dehydrogenation of alcohol to form the corresponding aldehyde; (2) non-catalytic condensation between aldehyde and ammonia to yield the primary imine; and (3) hydrogenation of imine to produce the primary amine. The first step has been recognized as the rate-determining step, which necessitates the employment of much higher temperatures than that required for reductive amination of aldehyde/ketones. Meanwhile, side reactions in competition are susceptible to occur in view of the stronger nucleophilicity of accumulated alkyl amine products than ammonia towards carbonyl groups, leading to the formation of secondary amine and tertiary amine by-products [4]. While a large number of catalyst systems including homogeneous Ru and Ir catalysts [7–9], heterogeneous noble metal Pt [10], Pd [11], and Ru [12–14] catalysts, and non-noble metal catalysts like Ni [4,15], Cu [16,17], and Co [18] have been developed for alcohol amination, challenges remain to be addressed such as the low selectivity to primary amines at high alcohol conversions, the high cost of noble metals and the low efficiency of non-noble metals, as well as the harsh reaction conditions. To tackle these challenges, it is highly desired to develop novel catalyst materials which can substantially save the use of expensive noble metals meanwhile exhibit high activity and selectivity to primary amines under milder reaction conditions. Single-atom alloy (SAA) catalysts that comprise catalytically active elements typically like noble metals alloyed in a more inert host metals like non-noble transition metals at the single-atom limit [19–21] emerge as an attractive strategy to maximize the noble metal efficiency meanwhile maintaining the high selectivity intrinsically to the host metal. In the past years, SAA catalysts have been reported to show superior performances in selective hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds [22–25], alkane dehydrogenation [21,26,27], and alcohol dehydrogenation [28,29] reactions, which could be attributed to the well-defined and uniform structure, isolated active metal center, and the electronic modification by the second metal. Pera-Titus and coworkers reported two dilute alloy catalysts, 5Co98.5-Ru1.5 and 5Co98.5Ag1.5, which afforded 90% conversion and 78% yield of 1-octylamine in the 1-octanol amination reaction at 200 °C [30]. Later, Pera-Titus, Sautet and coworkers made an excellent theoretical analysis for the alcohol amination reaction by using first-principle calculations, scaling relations and kinetic simulations [31], and proposed that the C–N bond coupling between CH3NH and CH2NH intermediates could be used as a descriptor for selectivity. Moreover, their predictions about the best formulations of dilute alloys were in good agreement with the experiments results. In spite of this significant achievement, the structures of such good-performance dilute alloy catalysts were not clearly characterized, and it is unknown if the SAA structure is responsible for the enhanced activity. In our recent work [32], we prepared a series of Ru-Co/HAP catalysts with varied Ru/Co ratios and applied to the reductive amination of furfural. We found that after reduction treatment, significant phase segregation occurred and Ru was greatly enriched on the surface. Only at Co/Ru atomic ratio ≥ 20 was a surface Ru1CoNP SAA structure formed. The formation of such surface SAA structure was the key to the transformation of furfural to piperidine. Obviously, the surface SAA structure has distinct properties towards the adsorption and surface reaction of intermediates from conventional metal alloys, which is worthwhile to be further explored. Inspired by the above-mentioned studies, herein we investigated different metal oxides supported Ru-Co alloy catalysts for the liquid-phase alcohol amination reaction with ammonia in the presence of H2. Both the Co/Ru ratio and the support nature were found to impose significant effects on activity and selectivity, with the Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 affording the highest yield of primary amine (74.2%) under mild reaction conditions. Characterizations showed that the Ru1-Co30 catalyst was comprised of both Ru single atoms and clusters while the slightly less active Ru1-Co60 catalyst was fully composed of a SAA structure. The real active site for the alcohol amination reaction was believed to be the SAA structure, and the slightly higher activity of the Ru1-Co30 than Ru1-Co60 was due to the higher number of active sites on the former catalyst. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) experiments revealed that the SAA structure significantly weakened the adsorption of aldehyde intermediate which would be otherwise over-strongly adsorbed on the Co surface, thus releasing the active sites for alcohol dehydrogenation. This promotional mechanism is quite distinct from the previous reports, and thus sheds new light on the synergy of SAA catalysts for the alcohol amination. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation ZrO2 was prepared by a modified procedure based on literature [33]. Typically, 21.65 g of urea were dissolved in 40 mL of deionized water and stirred at 600 rpm. 12.65 g of ZrO(NO3)2·xH2O were dissolved in 30 mL of deionized water and sonicated for 10 min, then added into urea solution slowly and stirred at 700 rpm for 10 min. The mixture was transferred into an autoclave and heated at 180 °C in an oven for 20 h. After the crystallization under autogenous pressure, the resulting precipitate was recovered by centrifugation and thorough washing and dried in an oven at 110 °C overnight. The dried sample was ground to fine powder and calcined in a muffle furnace at 400 °C for 4 h at a heating rate of 5 °C/min to obtain the ZrO2 support. The Ru x -Co y /ZrO2 (x/y refers to molar ratio of Ru to Co, and the total metal loading was fixed at 5 wt%) catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method. Taking the preparation of Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 as an example. 231 mg of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (Aladdin, AR, 99%) and 81.8 mg of the Ruthenium(III) chloride solution (the Ru content of the solution was 3.29 wt%) were added into 1 mL of deionized water and sonicated for 10 min, followed by addition of 1 g ZrO2. The impregnated sample was dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight and calcined at 400 °C for 3 h at a heating rate of 5 °C/min under static air. Then, the calcined sample was reduced at 350 °C for 2 h under a 5 v/v% (H2/Ar) gas flow, and passivated under a 1 v/v% (O2/Ar) gas flow at room temperature for 10 h. For comparison, different supported bimetallic and monometallic catalysts were prepared by the same procedure as that for Ru1-Co30/ZrO2. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a PANalytical X’pert diffractometer using Cu kα radiation source (λ = 0.154 nm) with a scanning angle (2θ) of 10°–80°, operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. The actual Co and Ru loadings of catalysts were determined by inductively coupled plasma spectroscopy (ICP-OES) on an IRIS Intrepid II XSP instrument (Thermo Electron Corporation). X-ray absorption spectra (XAS) including X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) at Ru K-edge of the samples were measured at the beamline 14W of Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF) in China. The energy was calibrated by Ru foil. The data were collected at room temperature under fluorescence mode. Athena software package was employed to process the XAS data. The reducibility of catalysts was measured by H2 temperature programmed reduction (TPR) on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 System. 80 mg of the calcined sample was transferred to a quartz tube and heated at 300 °C for 1 h under Ar flow. After cooling down to 50 °C, the gas was switched to 10 vol% H2/Ar flow and the sample was heated to 900 °C using a temperature ramp of 10 °C/min at a flow rate of 30 mL/min. A cooling trap was placed before the detector. The chemisorption of CO was performed on the same instrument. Prior to the measurement, the calcined sample was in-situ reduced at 350 °C for 2 h under a 10 vol% H2/Ar flow (30 mL/min) and then purged at 360 °C for 30 min under Ar flow. After cooling down to 50 °C, CO was dosed until saturation was reached. Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) experiments were performed on a JEOL JEM-2100F microscope equipped with an Oxford Instruments ISIS/INCA and operated at 200 kV. Before the examination, the samples were ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol and dropped on a copper TEM grid for observation. The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were measured using an ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer operated at 12.5 kV and 16 mA, equipping with an Al Kα X-ray radiation source (hv = 1486.6 eV). The passing energy was 40 eV and the binding energies were calibrated using C 1s peak at 284.6 eV. Before the measurements, the samples were in-situ activated at 350 °C for 2 h under a 10 vol% H2/Ar flow and then transferred to the chamber without exposure to air. During argon ion etching, the energy of argon ion was 3 keV, with an ion beam etching rate of 1 nm/s. The temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) was performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 System with ethanol was the probe molecule. Prior to testing, the catalyst sample was in-situ activated at 350 °C for 2 h under a 10 vol% H2/Ar flow. After cooling to 40 °C, the gas was switched to ethanol-saturated Ar flow (30 mL/min) and the sample was heated to 400 °C using a temperature ramp of 10 °C/min. The effluent gas was continually monitored by a MS. The temperature-programmed desorption of aldehyde was performed with a similar procedure except bubbling the Ar gas using acetaldehyde dissolved in THF. The diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS) of CO adsorbed on different catalysts were recorded on a Bruker Equinox 55 IR spectroscope equipped with a MCT detector. Prior to adsorption, the catalyst sample was in-situ activated at 350 °C for 2 h under a 10 vol% H2/Ar flow. After cooling down to room temperature, a 10% CO/He gas flow (30 mL/min) was introduced to the catalyst for adsorption until saturation. Then, the gas was switched to He flow and the spectra were recorded under He flow until no change was observed. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiment was performed under air flow (50 mL/min) from 20 to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min using a SDT Q600 instrument with the QSeries software. 2.3 Reaction tests The alcohol amination reaction tests were performed in a batch reactor system. In a typical reaction for the amination of 1-octanol, 0.5 mmol 1-octanol (Aladdin, AR), 55 mg catalyst and 3.5 mL of p-xylene (Alfa, anhydrous) were added into a 50 mL stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was purged with NH3 for five times, and charged with 0.7 MPa NH3 and 0.3 MPa H2 at room temperature. Then the reaction mixture was heated to 160 °C in 30 min and reacted for 1.5 h with a stirring rate of 600 rpm. After the reaction, the liquid-phase products were analyzed by a GC (Agilent 7890A) equipped with a HP-5 column and a flame ionized detector with dodecane as the internal standard. The conversion of 1-octanol and the selectivity and yield of products were calculated using the following equations: (1) X (1-octanol) = (moloctanol, consumed)/(moloctanol, fed) × 100% (2) S = (mol of carbon in specific product)/(mol of carbon in comsumed 1-octanol) × 100% (3) Y (1-octylamine) = (mol1-octylamine, produced)/(moloctanol, fed) × 100% where X, S and Y refer to the conversion, selectivity and yield, respectively. The turnover rate (TOR) of the catalyst was calculated based on the initial conversion of 1-octanol (~ 20%) by adjusting the reaction time to ensure the reaction was in a kinetically controlled region. For the stability test, the catalyst after the reaction was recovered by filtration and repetitive washing with ethanol, and then dried at 60 °C for 5 h before being submitted to the next run. For the catalyst regeneration, the spent catalyst was calcined and activated under the same conditions as those used for the preparation of the fresh catalyst, and then employed in the catalytic reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The effect of Ru/Co ratio and support nature on the catalytic performance We initially selected the amination of 1-octanol as the probe reaction. A series of Ru-Co/ZrO2 catalysts were evaluated under mild reaction condition of 160 °C, 0.7 MPa NH3 and 0.3 MPa H2. The results were summarized in Table 1 . Compared to monometallic Co/ZrO2 and Ru/ZrO2 catalysts which showed only minor conversions of 1-octanol (entries 6, 7), all the bimetallic Ru-Co catalysts gave rise to markedly increased activities (entries 1–5). Moreover, the activity strongly depended on the nominal Ru/Co ratios. With a decrease of the Ru/Co ratio from 1/1 to 1/120 while keeping the total metal content the same (5 wt%), the conversion of 1-octanol increased first and reached the highest value of 92.8% after 1.5 h at Ru/Co ratio of 1/30 (entry 3), and then slightly decreased to 90.9% at Ru/Co ratio of 1/60 (entry 2) and further to 73.1% at Ru/Co ratio of 1/120 (entry 1). In view of the primary amine yield, a volcano-like dependence on the Ru/Co ratio can be clearly seen: Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 > Ru1-Co60/ZrO2 > Ru1-Co120/ZrO2 > Ru1-Co10/ ZrO2 > Ru1-Co1/ZrO2 > Co/ZrO2. Calculation of the TOR based on the initial conversion revealed that the TOR over the Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalyst was 8.4 times higher (11.8 h–1 vs. 1.4 h–1) than that over the Co/ZrO2 catalyst. Obviously, the remarkable enhancement in the activity took place only at an extremely dilute Ru concentration (Ru/Co ≤ 30), above which the promotional effect of Ru was alleviated. When compared to literature, we found that our Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalyst was one of the most active catalysts, outperforming most of the reported catalysts and approaching the activity of the most active Ru/HBEA catalyst [14] (Fig. S1). More importantly, compared to Ru/HBEA catalyst, our SAA catalyst achieved this superior performance with a significantly reduced Ru loading (0.2 wt% vs. 5 wt%) and operated at a lower temperature (160 °C vs. 180 °C), highlighting the prominent advantages of SAA catalysts in cutting down the cost of catalysts. Kinetic study on the Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalyst showed that, except for the secondary amine, no any other byproducts were observed during the whole reaction period (Fig. S2). The absence of aldehyde-related intermediates should be ascribed to the instability and high reactivity of the aldehydes. Interestingly, the selectivity to primary amine (b) did not change much with the variation of Ru/Co ratio. This was further confirmed by varying the reaction time to keep almost the same conversions over catalysts with different Ru/Co ratios (Fig. S3). It can be seen that, at a low conversion level (< 20%), both monometallic and bimetallic catalysts gave > 99% selectivity towards primary amine (Fig. S3(a)). By contrast, at a high conversion level (~ 90%), all the Ru-Co bimetallic catalysts exhibited superior selectivity to monometallic Ru and Co catalysts (Fig. S3(b)), indicating the primary amine was more favored over the Ru-Co bimetallic catalysts. Control experiment with a mechanical mixture of Co/ZrO2 and Ru/ZrO2 with the same Ru/Co ratio and the same total metal loading as those in the Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalyst resulted in a conversion of only 45% (entry 9), only half that over the Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalyst, demonstrating a pronounced synergistic effect between Co and Ru. In addition to Ru/Co ratio, the support nature also imposed a remarkable effect on both conversion and selectivity. The Al2O3-supported Ru1-Co30 and Ru1-Co60 catalysts (entries 10, 11) gave rise to activity and selectivity comparable to the ZrO2-supported analogues, suggesting that the bimetallic structures in the two catalysts were similar. By contrast, HAP, SiO2, BN, and TiO2 supported Ru1-Co30 bimetallic catalysts exhibited much lower activity and selectivity (entries 12–15). According to our previous work [32], the support nature could influence the actual surface Ru/Co ratio due to the hydrogen-induced phase segregation, which in turn affected the catalytic performance. Among various transition metals, Ru was found to exert the most pronounced effect on Co. As shown in Table S1, Ag-Co, Pd-Co and Pt-Co bimetallic catalysts all exhibited superior activity to monometallic Co, but to a less extent than Ru-Co bimetallic catalyst. Thereby, in the following part we will focus on the Ru-Co bimetallic catalysts to decipher the mechanism for synergy between Ru and Co. 3.2 Structure and surface properties of catalysts Aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) imaging was performed to probe the catalyst microstructure. Unfortunately, Co and Ru atoms were indistinguishable on ZrO2 support due to the serious interference from Zr (Fig. S4). Considering that the Al2O3-supported Ru-Co catalysts exhibited very close activity and selectivity to ZrO2-supported ones (Table 1), we hypothesize they possess the similar structure for the Ru-Co nanoparticles. Therefore, we examined the Al2O3-supported monometallic Ru, Co and bimetallic Ru-Co catalysts because they could provide high-quality images with good contrast. STEM images showed that the particles in the three Co-containing samples were not uniform, ranging from 5 to 20 nm (Fig. S5). The monometallic Co/Al2O3 catalyst showed an average particle size of 13.9 nm whereas the Ru/Al2O3 catalyst gave an average particle size of only 1.4 nm due to the low concentration of Ru. By contrast, the average particle sizes were 9.2 and 11.3 nm for the Ru1-Co30/Al2O3 and Ru1-Co60/Al2O3 catalysts, respectively, indicating that the introduction of Ru could limit the aggregation of Co particles. The smaller particle size of the Ru1-Co30/Al2O3 could account for the slightly higher activity than the Ru1-Co60/Al2O3 catalyst. Fig. 1(a) shows the high-resolution HAADF-STEM images of the Ru1-Co30/Al2O3 catalyst. Both the lattice spacing and FFT pattern indicated metallic Co phase. Moreover, the presence of bright and dark atoms in the image suggested the formation of Ru-Co alloy phase because Ru atoms appear brighter than Co atoms due to the higher atomic number of Ru. The line intensity profiles of the rectangular regions clearly demonstrated the presence of isolated Ru single atoms as well as Ru clusters of a few atoms. The elemental mapping with EDS indicated that Ru atoms are predominantly located on Co NPs rather than on the support. The line scan analysis was conducted on randomly selected Co particles (Fig. 1(e)), which showed complete overlap of Co and Ru signals, thus providing strong evidence that they form alloy structure. The Ru K-edge X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) characterization was performed to determine the electronic and coordination structure of Ru1-Co60/Al2O3 catalyst. The XANES spectra at Ru K-edge in Fig. 2(a) showed the same absorption edge energy as that of Ru foil, suggesting that Ru species on the Ru1-Co60/Al2O3 catalyst exist in a metallic state. The coordination structure was revealed by EXAFS at Ru K-edge. As shown in Fig. 2(b), for the Ru1-Co60/Al2O3 catalyst, there was only one intense peak at 2.2 Å which could be ascribed to Ru-Co bond. No Ru-Ru coordination was detected, indicating that Ru atom was isolated by the surrounding Co atoms and formed pure single-atom alloy structure. The best-fitted result showed that the Ru-Co coordination number was 9.5 at a Ru-Co distance of 2.52 Å (Table S2). The much smaller Ru-Co coordination number in the Ru1-Co60/Al2O3 catalyst than Ru foil indicated that Ru was in the surface or subsurface rather than in the bulk of the NPs, which was in accordance with our previous work [32]. The surface composition and electronic structure of the Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 were probed by XPS in the Ru 3p and Co 2p core-level regions (Fig. 3 ). The peak at 461.6 eV in the Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalyst was associated with Ru0 [34,35], which was lowered by 0.6 eV than that in Ru1-Co10/ZrO2 sample, suggesting that there was electron transfer from Co to Ru, which was in line with the higher electronegativity of Ru (2.2) compared to Co (1.88). The lower electron density of Ru in the Ru1-Co10/ZrO2 sample could potentially account for the observed decrease in catalytic activity [36,37]. In the Co 2p core-level region, there were two sets of peaks which could be attributed to Co0 and Co2+ [38–40]. The presence of Co2+ was probably due to the incomplete reduction of the calcined sample in the XPS chamber. Comparing the Co0 peak in the two samples, it was found that there was not any shift in the binding energies. This could be reasonable considering that the Co concentration was more than 20 times that of Ru based on ICP analysis (Table S3). Semi-quantification by XPS revealed that the surface Ru/Co ratio was 1:2.84, which was almost an order of magnitude larger than the bulk ratio, indicating that Ru was significantly enriched on the surface, which was induced by H2 reduction according to our previous work [32]. To further prove the surface enrichment of Ru, we conducted Ar ion etching before XPS. The etching depth was around 0.3 nm, roughly equivalent to one atom depth. The results showed that no Ru element was detected after Ar etching, suggesting that most of the Ru single atoms were on the surface or in the subsurface of Co NPs, in accordance with the EXAFS result. The surface properties were further probed with DRIFTS of CO adsorption. As shown in Fig. 4 , two absorption bands were observed for monometallic Ru/ZrO2 catalyst. The intense band at 2058 cm–1 was assigned to linearly adsorbed CO on Ru0 (Ru0-CO), while the weak and broad band at 1985 cm–1 was assigned to bridge-bonded CO (Ru2-CO) [41]. For the bimetallic Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalyst, both the linearly and bridge-bonded CO bands had a redshift, suggesting that the Ru sites in the bimetallic catalyst were more electron-rich, which was in line with the XPS result. The presence of both linearly and bridge-bonded CO and the relatively larger ratio of linear- to bridged-CO band areas suggested that both Ru single atoms and clusters co-existed in the Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalyst with the dominance of the Ru single atoms, which was consistent with the HAADF-STEM imaging result. By contrast, for the more dilute sample Ru1-Co60/ZrO2, the bridge-bonded CO band disappeared completely, while the linearly-bonded CO had a more red-shift, indicating the Ru atoms were sufficiently isolated single atoms and got more electrons from the surrounding Co atoms. This result was coherent with the EXAFS result. Taking account of the high activity for alcohol amination of the Ru1-Co60/ZrO2 catalyst (Table 1) and the pure SAA structure, we can claim that the Ru-Co SAA structure was responsible for the activity, and the slightly higher activity of Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 than Ru1-Co60/ZrO2 could be ascribed to the smaller particle size of the former catalyst. To shed light on the interaction between Ru and Co, we performed H2-TPR and H2-TPD experiments. As shown in Fig. 5(a) , the profile of Co/ZrO2 showed two peaks at 220 and 388 °C corresponding to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and CoO to Co [42,43]. Compared to monometallic Co/ZrO2, the H2-TPR profile of the Ru1-Co60/ZrO2 changed remarkably, with the two reduction peaks less resolved and the significant shift towards low temperature of the second peak. This result indicated that even the presence of a tiny amount of Ru could promote greatly the reduction of Co2+ to metallic Co. With a further increase of the Ru content to a Ru/Co ratio of 1/30, the reduction peak shifted to a lower temperature. Due to the promotional reduction of Co by Ru, all the Co species in the bimetallic catalysts were reduced to metallic state at 350 °C, as indicated by XRD patterns (Fig. S7). The H2-TPD profiles in Fig. 5(b) showed two desorption peaks characteristic of weak and strong interaction with the catalysts. Compared to Co/ZrO2, both the Ru1-Co60/ZrO2 and Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalysts presented much more intense peaks at a higher temperature, suggesting the presence of Ru single atoms strengthened the interaction with hydrogen molecules, which would be favorable to the alcohol dehydrogenation [44,45], the rate-determining step in the alcohol amination [12]. A control experiment with octanal to replace 1-octanol in the reduction amination reaction revealed that both Co/ZrO2 and Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalysts delivered 100% conversion (Table S4) although the former gave a lower selectivity to primary amine, corroborating alcohol dehydrogenation is the rate-determining step in the alcohol amination. In order to unveil the role of Ru single atoms in the alcohol amination over the Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalyst, alcohol-based TPSR (Alcohol-TPSR) experiments were designed to evaluate the alcohol dehydrogenation ability on Ru1-Co30/ZrO2, Co/ZrO2 and Ru/ZrO2 catalysts. For this purpose, ethanol was employed as the probe molecule considering that it could be easily introduced into a continuous flow reactor system by bubbling with inert gas. The results are shown in Fig. 6 . The dehydrogenation products, acetaldehyde and hydrogen, were detected with an increase of temperature. Comparing the temperatures at which the dehydrogenation products appeared, one can clearly see the trend following the order of Ru/ZrO2 < Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 < Co/ZrO2, which strongly suggests that Ru single atoms greatly promote the alcohol dehydrogenation, the key step in the alcohol amination. The much higher temperature observed for desorption of acetaldehyde over the Co/ZrO2 catalyst (Fig. 6(c)) suggests that the strong adsorption of aldehyde on the Co surface should be the reason for its poor activity for alcohol amination. By forming single-atom alloy structure, the adsorption behavior of the Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalyst was substantially modified so that the adsorption of aldehyde was significantly weakened. Probably, the strong adsorption of aldehyde on the Co surface will poison the active sites for dehydrogenation. By contrast, the weak adsorption of aldehyde on the Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalyst will release the active sites by desorption, allowing for the alcohol dehydrogenation on the same active sites. The distinct adsorption behavior of Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 single-atom alloy catalyst was similar to the previous report that NiCo alloys significantly changed the binding energy of aldehydes [46]. Based on the characterization and analysis described above, we proposed a plausible mechanism for alcohols amination over the Ru1-Co n single-atom alloy catalyst (Fig. S8). Initially, the alcohol is adsorbed on the Ru1-Co n single-atom alloy and undergoes dehydrogenation to form intermediate aldehyde and H species [36,37,47]. The presence of Ru single atoms weakens the adsorption of aldehyde, promoting its rapid desorption from the active sites. The desorbed aldehyde then reacts with ammonia to produce imines. Subsequently, imines are hydrogenated by the H species generated from alcohol dehydrogenation or supplied externally to form primary amines. Finally, the primary amine is desorbed to complete the catalytic cycle. On one hand, compared to monometallic Co catalyst, the Ru1-Co SAA structure greatly promoted the dehydrogenation of alcohols and the hydrogenation of imines immediately upon their formation, thus increasing both activity and selectivity. On the other hand, compared to pure Ru surface which was reported to have a stronger adsorption for primary amine than Co surface [31], the SAA structure well maintained the suitable adsorption strength for primary amine so that it could be desorbed with a low energy barrier, thus avoiding its further transformation to secondary amine. 3.3 Substrate scope and reusability of catalyst The best-performance Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalyst was used for substrate scope investigation. As shown in Table 2 , short-chain aliphatic alcohols exhibited lower reactivity than long-chain ones, and the presence of branch in the chain further reduced the activity due to steric hindrance. By contrast, cyclic aliphatic alcohols showed higher reaction activity and selectivity, which could be attributed to the formation of more sterically hindered imine intermediate, thereby reducing the occurrence of side reactions [13]. In the case of aromatic alcohols, the presence of electron-donating groups decreased the reaction activity, whereas electron-withdrawing groups such as halogen substituent enhanced both activity and selectivity to varying degrees. This suggested that electron-withdrawing groups favor the amination of alcohols. Overall, the Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalyst could be applied to the amination of a broad scope of alcohols with satisfactory yields to primary amines. The stability of the Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalyst was evaluated in 1-octanol amination. As shown in Fig. S9(a), after two cycles, the conversion of 1-octanol dropped down to 52%, while the selectivity of primary amine increased slightly. The TGA (Fig. S10) of the used catalyst exhibited weight losses at around 200 and 400 °C, corresponding to desorption of the organic compounds and the oxidation of carbon species, respectively [18]. The deactivated catalyst could be regenerated by calcination and reduction, offering the same activity as the fresh one, suggesting that coking was primarily responsible for the observed deactivation. Moreover, ICP analysis of the regenerated catalyst revealed almost identical metal contents to the fresh catalyst (Table S3), indicating negligible leaching of metals during the reaction. To further evaluate the structural stability of the Ru-Co SAA catalyst, the catalyst was submitted to five cycles of regeneration and reaction tests and exhibited excellent stability (Fig. S9(b)). The regenerated catalyst was characterized with HAADF-STEM imaging which showed the existence of both Ru single atoms and clusters (Fig. S11). These results have demonstrated excellent stability of the SAA structure, showing great potential for practical applications. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have developed Ru1-Con single-atom alloy catalytic system for alcohols amination to access primary amines. The incorporation of a very dilute concentration of Ru (30 ≤ Co/Ru ≤ 60) resulted in a significant increase in catalytic activity compared to the Co/ZrO2 catalyst. Structural characterization confirmed that the Ru atoms in the Ru1-Co60/ZrO2 sample were isolated by the surrounding Co atoms, forming a single-atom alloy structure. Further analysis revealed that the Ru single atoms promoted the reduction of Co, enhanced the adsorption capacity of H₂ on the catalyst, most importantly, mitigated the over-strong adsorption of intermediate aldehyde on Co, which is crucial for improving catalytic performance. The best Ru1-Co30/ZrO2 catalyst demonstrated high activity, selectivity and stability of regeneration as well as great tolerance to a broad scope of alcohols. This study provides new insights into the mechanism for synergy in the single-atom alloy catalysts and opens a new avenue to the design of low-cost and efficient catalysts for alcohols amination. coredata.dc:description: Synthesis of primary amines from alcohols is an economical and green route to access high-value N-compounds. However, challenges remain to develop both cost-effective and efficient catalysts. In this study, we developed a Ru-Co/ZrO2 single-atom alloy catalyst which afforded diverse primary amines from alcohols in the presence of ammonia and hydrogen with exceptional conversion (up to 90%) and selectivity (80%) under mild conditions (0.7 MPa NH3, 0.3 MPa H2, 160 °C) and exhibited satisfactory stability upon regeneration. The turnover rate was approximately 8.4 times higher than that observed over the Co/ZrO2 catalyst. Characterizations indicated that the alloyed Ru facilitated the reduction of Co, strengthened the interaction with H2 and mitigated the over-strong adsorption of aldehyde intermediates. These combined effects contributed significantly to the enhanced catalytic performances. This work presents a promising strategy for the development of advanced catalysts in the amination of alcohols.
